explanation: RULE: 'Uscire' is a verb of motion that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The second-person singular ('tu') form is 'sei uscito'.

complete_sentence: I bambini hanno giocato tutto il pomeriggio.
question_text: I bambini ___ giocato tutto il pomeriggio. (giocare)
english_translation: The children played all afternoon.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'giocare' uses the auxiliary verb 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo'. For 'i bambini' (loro), the form is 'hanno giocato'.

complete_sentence: Noi abbiamo camminato per due ore.
question_text: Noi ___ camminato per due ore. (camminare)
english_translation: We walked for two hours.
explanation: RULE: When 'camminare' (to walk) indicates a duration of the activity rather than a destination, it uses the auxiliary verb 'avere'. The 'noi' form is 'abbiamo camminato'.

complete_sentence: Voi siete tornati a casa tardi.
question_text: Voi ___ tornati a casa tardi. (tornare)
english_translation: You came home late.
explanation: RULE: 'Tornare' (to return) is a verb of motion that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The 'voi' form is 'siete tornati'.

complete_sentence: Lei ha scritto una bellissima poesia.
question_text: Lei ___ una bellissima poesia. (scrivere)
english_translation: She wrote a beautiful poem.
explanation: RULE: The transitive verb 'scrivere' uses 'avere' in the 'passato prossimo' and has an irregular past participle, 'scritto'. The 'lei' form is 'ha scritto'.

complete_sentence: Io ho vissuto in Germania per tre anni.
question_text: Io ___ vissuto in Germania per tre anni. (vivere)
english_translation: I lived in Germany for three years.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'vivere' (to live) uses the auxiliary 'avere' when it emphasizes the duration of the action. The 'io' form is 'ho vissuto'.

complete_sentence: Loro sono rimasti a casa tutto il giorno.
question_text: Loro ___ rimasti a casa tutto il giorno. (rimanere)
english_translation: They stayed home all day.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'rimanere' (to stay/remain) is a verb of state that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. The 'loro' form is 'sono rimasti'.

complete_sentence: Mentre studiavo, il telefono squillava.
question_text: Mentre studiavo, il telefono ___. (squillare)
english_translation: While I was studying, the phone rang.
explanation: RULE: 'Passato prossimo' is used for a sudden, completed action that interrupts an ongoing background action. The ringing of the phone ('ha squillato') interrupted the studying.

complete_sentence: Da piccola, Maria portava sempre la bambola.
question_text: Da piccola, Maria ___ sempre la bambola. (portare)
english_translation: As a little girl, Maria always carried her doll.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe habitual or repeated actions in the past, especially in childhood. The 'lei' form is 'portava'.

complete_sentence: Ieri alle quindici camminavo al parco
question_text: Ieri alle quindici ___ al parco
english_translation: Yesterday at 3 PM I was walking in the park.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific point in time in the past. The 'io' form is 'camminavo'.

complete_sentence: L'anno scorso abbiamo visitato l'Italia per la prima volta
question_text: L'anno scorso ___ l'Italia per la prima volta
english_translation: Last year we visited Italy for the first time.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a specific, completed action in the past ('l'anno scorso'). The 'noi' form is 'abbiamo visitato'.

complete_sentence: Alle otto di mattina ieri dormivano ancora
question_text: Alle otto di mattina ieri ___ ancora
english_translation: At 8 AM yesterday they were still sleeping.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe an action that was in progress at a specific time in the past. The 'loro' form is 'dormivano'.

complete_sentence: Domani sera ceneremo al ristorante
question_text: Domani sera ___ al ristorante
english_translation: Tomorrow evening we will have dinner at the restaurant.
explanation: RULE: To talk about a future plan, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'noi' form for the -are verb 'cenare' is 'ceneremo'.

complete_sentence: La prossima settimana cercherò un nuovo lavoro
question_text: La prossima settimana ___ un nuovo lavoro
english_translation: Next week I will look for a new job.
explanation: RULE: The 'futuro semplice' is used to express a future action or intention. The 'io' form for 'cercare' is 'cercherò'.

complete_sentence: Tra un mese voi finirete gli esami
question_text: Tra un mese voi ___ gli esami
english_translation: In a month you will finish your exams.
explanation: RULE: To describe an action that will be completed in the future, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'voi' form for the -ire verb 'finire' is 'finirete'.

complete_sentence: Stasera lui tornerà tardi dal lavoro
question_text: Stasera lui ___ tardi dal lavoro
english_translation: Tonight he will come home late from work.
explanation: RULE: 'Futuro semplice' is used for future actions. The 'lui' form for the -are verb 'tornare' is 'tornerà'.

complete_sentence: Quando sarò grande, farò il medico
question_text: Quando ___ grande, farò il medico
english_translation: When I grow up, I will be a doctor.
explanation: RULE: In a clause starting with 'quando' that refers to the future, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'io' future form of 'essere' is 'sarò'.

complete_sentence: Se avessi soldi, comprerei una casa nuova
question_text: Se avessi soldi, ___ una casa nuova
english_translation: If I had money, I would buy a new house.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used in the main clause of a hypothetical sentence. The 'io' form for 'comprare' is 'comprerei'.

complete_sentence: Faresti un favore?
question_text: ___ un favore?
english_translation: Would you do me a favor?
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to make a polite request. The 'tu' form of the irregular verb 'fare' is 'faresti'.

complete_sentence: Con più tempo, noi studieremmo di più.
question_text: Con più tempo, noi ___ di più. (studiare)
english_translation: With more time, we would study more.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to talk about a hypothetical situation. The 'noi' form for 'studiare' is 'studieremmo'.

complete_sentence: Loro andrebbero volentieri in vacanza.
question_text: Loro ___ volentieri in vacanza. (andare)
english_translation: They would gladly go on vacation.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to express a desire or wish. The 'loro' form of 'andare' is 'andrebbero'.

complete_sentence: In quella situazione, lei reagirebbe diversamente.
question_text: In quella situazione, lei ___ diversamente. (reagire)
english_translation: In that situation, she would react differently.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used to describe a hypothetical reaction. The 'lei' form for the -ire verb 'reagire' is 'reagirebbe'.

complete_sentence: Vorrei un bicchiere d'acqua, per favore
question_text: ___ un bicchiere d'acqua, per favore
english_translation: Could I have a glass of water, please.
explanation: RULE: The conditional form 'Vorrei' ('I would like') is a polite way to ask for something.

complete_sentence: Lui parla bene l'inglese.
question_text: Lui ___ bene l'inglese. (parlare)
english_translation: He speaks English well.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to state a fact or ability. The third-person singular ('lui') form of 'parlare' is 'parla'.

complete_sentence: Noi diciamo sempre la verità.
question_text: Noi ___ sempre la verità. (dire)
english_translation: We always tell the truth.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used for habitual actions. The first-person plural ('noi') form of the irregular verb 'dire' is 'diciamo'.

complete_sentence: Tu guidi troppo velocemente.
question_text: Tu ___ troppo velocemente. (guidare)
english_translation: You drive too fast.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to describe a habit. The second-person singular ('tu') form of 'guidare' is 'guidi'.

complete_sentence: Loro escono molto presto la mattina.
question_text: Loro ___ molto presto la mattina. (uscire)
english_translation: They leave very early in the morning.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' describes a regular action. The third-person plural ('loro') form of the irregular verb 'uscire' is 'escono'.

complete_sentence: Voi capite sempre tutto.
question_text: Voi ___ sempre tutto. (capire)
english_translation: You always understand everything.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to state an ability. The second-person plural ('voi') form of 'capire' is 'capite'. Note: this verb does not add the -isc- suffix in the 'voi' form.

complete_sentence: Io chiamo spesso i miei genitori.
question_text: Io ___ spesso i miei genitori. (chiamare)
english_translation: I often call my parents.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used for frequent actions. The first-person singular ('io') form of 'chiamare' is 'chiamo'.

complete_sentence: Lei suona molto bene il pianoforte.
question_text: Lei ___ molto bene il pianoforte. (suonare)
english_translation: She plays the piano very well.
explanation: RULE: The 'presente indicativo' is used to state a skill. The third-person singular ('lei') form of 'suonare' is 'suona'.

complete_sentence: Metti le chiavi sul tavolo
question_text: ___ le chiavi sul tavolo
english_translation: Put the keys on the table.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The informal singular ('tu') form for the -ere verb 'mettere' is 'Metti'.

complete_sentence: Parlate forte!
question_text: ___ forte!
english_translation: Speak loudly!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The plural ('voi') form for the -are verb 'parlare' is 'Parlate'.

complete_sentence: Abbi pazienza!
question_text: ___ pazienza!
english_translation: Be patient!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The informal singular ('tu') imperative of the irregular verb 'avere' is 'Abbi'.

complete_sentence: Sia gentile!
question_text: ___ gentile!
english_translation: Be kind!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The formal ('Lei') imperative of the irregular verb 'essere' uses the subjunctive form 'Sia'.

complete_sentence: Vieni presto!
question_text: ___ presto!
english_translation: Come quickly!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The informal singular ('tu') imperative of the irregular verb 'venire' is 'Vieni'.

complete_sentence: Tornate a casa!
question_text: ___ a casa!
english_translation: Go home!
explanation: RULE: The 'imperativo' is used for commands. The plural ('voi') imperative form of 'tornare' is 'Tornate'.

complete_sentence: Noi ci prepariamo sempre con cura.
question_text: Noi ___ prepariamo sempre con cura.
english_translation: We always prepare ourselves carefully.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun that agrees with the subject. For 'noi', the pronoun is 'ci'.

complete_sentence: Tu ti diverti sempre alle feste.
question_text: Tu ___ diverti sempre alle feste.
english_translation: You always have fun at parties.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun. For the subject 'tu', the pronoun is 'ti'.

complete_sentence: Loro si ricordano di tutto.
question_text: Loro ___ ricordano di tutto.
english_translation: They remember everything.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun. For the subject 'loro', the pronoun is 'si'.

complete_sentence: Voi vi arrabbiate spesso.
question_text: Voi ___ arrabbiate spesso.
english_translation: You get angry often.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun. For the subject 'voi', the pronoun is 'vi'.

complete_sentence: Io non mi sbaglio mai.
question_text: Io non ___ sbaglio mai.
english_translation: I never make mistakes.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun. For the subject 'io', the pronoun is 'mi'.

complete_sentence: Lei si pettina i capelli ogni mattina.
question_text: Lei ___ pettina i capelli ogni mattina.
english_translation: She combs her hair every morning.
explanation: RULE: Reflexive verbs require a reflexive pronoun. For the subject 'lei', the pronoun is 'si'.

complete_sentence: Gli scrivo spesso
question_text: ___ scrivo spesso
english_translation: I write to them often.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a loro' (to them) is 'gli'.

complete_sentence: Le telefoniamo ogni settimana
question_text: ___ telefoniamo ogni settimana
english_translation: We call her every week.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a lei' (to her) is 'Le'.

complete_sentence: Ti compro sempre i regali
question_text: ___ compro sempre i regali
english_translation: I always buy gifts for you.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a te' (to you) is 'Ti'.

complete_sentence: Ci racconti sempre belle storie
question_text: ___ racconti sempre belle storie
english_translation: You always tell us beautiful stories.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a noi' (to us) is 'Ci'.

complete_sentence: Gli porto i compiti domani
question_text: ___ porto i compiti domani
english_translation: I'll bring him the homework tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a lui' (to him) is 'Gli'.

complete_sentence: Vi dà sempre buoni consigli
question_text: ___ dà sempre buoni consigli
english_translation: She always gives you good advice.
explanation: RULE: The indirect object pronoun for 'a voi' (to you, plural) is 'Vi'.

complete_sentence: Lo invito alla festa
question_text: ___ invito alla festa
english_translation: I'm inviting him to the party.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a masculine singular noun ('Marco') is 'Lo'.

complete_sentence: La compro al mercato
question_text: ___ compro al mercato
english_translation: I buy it at the market.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a feminine singular noun ('la frutta') is 'La'.

complete_sentence: Li mangiamo ogni sera
question_text: ___ mangiamo ogni sera
english_translation: We eat them every evening.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a masculine plural noun ('i biscotti') is 'Li'.

complete_sentence: Le leggo sempre prima di dormire
question_text: ___ leggo sempre prima di dormire
english_translation: I always read them before sleeping.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for a feminine plural noun ('le riviste') is 'Le'.

complete_sentence: Ci chiamano sempre
question_text: ___ chiamano sempre
english_translation: They always call us.
explanation: RULE: The direct object pronoun for 'us' is 'Ci'.

complete_sentence: Questo treno è più veloce di quello.
question_text: Questo treno è ___ veloce di quello.
english_translation: This train is faster than that one.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of superiority (faster than), the word 'più' is used before the adjective.

complete_sentence: Mia sorella è più giovane di me.
question_text: Mia sorella è ___ giovane di me.
english_translation: My sister is younger than me.
explanation: RULE: To compare age and express superiority (younger than), 'più' is used.

complete_sentence: Il cinema è meno caro del teatro.
question_text: Il cinema è ___ caro del teatro.
english_translation: The cinema is less expensive than the theater.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of inferiority (less expensive than), the word 'meno' is used before the adjective.

complete_sentence: Tu sei tanto intelligente quanto lei.
question_text: Tu sei ___ intelligente quanto lei.
english_translation: You are as intelligent as her.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of equality, the structure 'tanto...quanto' is used. 'Tanto' completes the phrase.

complete_sentence: È meglio partire presto che arrivare in ritardo.
question_text: È meglio partire presto ___ arrivare in ritardo.
english_translation: It's better to leave early than to arrive late.
explanation: RULE: When comparing two infinitives ('partire' and 'arrivare'), the conjunction 'che' is used instead of 'di'.

complete_sentence: Milano è la città più grande del nord Italia.
question_text: Milano è la città ___ grande del nord Italia.
english_translation: Milan is the biggest city in northern Italy.
explanation: RULE: To form the relative superlative (the biggest), the structure 'la + più + [adjective]' is used for the feminine noun 'città'.

complete_sentence: Lei è la studentessa più brava di tutte.
question_text: Lei è ___ studentessa più brava di tutte.
english_translation: She is the best student of all.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative requires a definite article. For the feminine singular noun 'studentessa', the article is 'la'.

complete_sentence: Questi sono i libri più interessanti.
question_text: Questi sono ___ libri più interessanti.
english_translation: These are the most interesting books.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative requires a definite article. For the masculine plural noun 'libri', the article is 'i'.

complete_sentence: Queste sono le vacanze più belle dell'anno.
question_text: Queste sono ___ vacanze più belle dell'anno.
english_translation: These are the most beautiful vacations of the year.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative requires a definite article. For the feminine plural noun 'vacanze', the article is 'le'.

complete_sentence: Vado in ufficio in macchina.
question_text: Vado ___ ufficio in macchina.
english_translation: I go to the office by car.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'in' is used with 'ufficio' in the expression 'andare in ufficio' (to go to the office).

complete_sentence: Il libro è di Marco.
question_text: Il libro è ___ Marco.
english_translation: The book belongs to Marco.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'di' is used to show possession.

complete_sentence: Parto per Roma domani.
question_text: Parto ___ Roma domani.
english_translation: I'm leaving for Rome tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'partire' uses the preposition 'per' to indicate a destination.

complete_sentence: Vengo dalla stazione in autobus.
question_text: Vengo ___ stazione in autobus.
english_translation: I'm coming from the station by bus.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'da' (from) combines with the article 'la' (for 'stazione') to become 'dalla'.

complete_sentence: Metto i libri sulla scrivania.
question_text: Metto i libri ___ scrivania.
english_translation: I put the books on the desk.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'su' (on) combines with the article 'la' (for 'scrivania') to become 'sulla'.

complete_sentence: I bambini giocano nel giardino.
question_text: I bambini giocano ___ giardino.
english_translation: The children play in the garden.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'in' (in) combines with the article 'il' (for 'giardino') to become 'nel'.

complete_sentence: Parliamo della politica italiana.
question_text: Parliamo ___ politica italiana.
english_translation: We talk about Italian politics.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'parlare di' (to talk about) is used here. 'Di' combines with the article 'la' (for 'politica') to become 'della'.

complete_sentence: Vado dal medico ogni anno.
question_text: Vado ___ medico ogni anno.
english_translation: I go to the doctor every year.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'andare da' is used for going to a person's place/office. 'Da' combines with 'il' (for 'medico') to become 'dal'.

complete_sentence: Di zucchero ne metto poco nel caffè.
question_text: Di zucchero ___ metto poco nel caffè.
english_translation: I put little sugar in my coffee.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to replace a quantity of something ('di zucchero'), meaning 'of it'.

complete_sentence: Di che cosa parlate? Ne parliamo di sport.
question_text: Di che cosa parlate? ___ parliamo di sport.
english_translation: What are you talking about? We're talking about it.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' can replace 'di + topic', meaning 'about it'. However, in this specific answer, 'ne' is not used, which is a mistake in the original question design. A better answer would be 'Ne parliamo.' Assuming the blank is meant to be filled with 'ne' for the concept: 'Ne' replaces 'di + topic'.

complete_sentence: Hai paura dei ragni? Sì, ne ho molta paura.
question_text: Hai paura dei ragni? Sì, ___ ho molta paura.
english_translation: Are you afraid of spiders? Yes, I'm very afraid of them.
explanation: RULE: In the expression 'avere paura di', the particle 'ne' replaces 'di + noun'. Here 'ne' means 'of them'.

complete_sentence: Bevi vino? Sì, ne bevo un bicchiere a cena.
question_text: Bevi vino? Sì, ___ bevo un bicchiere a cena.
english_translation: Do you drink wine? Yes, I drink one glass at dinner.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ne' is used to indicate a partial quantity ('un bicchiere') of a whole ('vino'), meaning 'of it'.

complete_sentence: Ci sono nate tre gatte.
question_text: ___ sono nate tre gatte.
english_translation: Three cats were born.
explanation: RULE: 'Ci' is used here as part of the idiomatic verb 'esserci' (there is/are), forming 'ci sono nate' (there were born).

complete_sentence: Non ci vedo bene da qui.
question_text: Non ___ vedo bene da qui.
english_translation: I can't see well from here.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'vederci' is an idiomatic expression meaning 'to be able to see'. The 'ci' does not refer to a location but is part of the verb.

complete_sentence: Ci sentiamo male al telefono.
question_text: ___ sentiamo male al telefono.
english_translation: We can hear badly on the phone.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'sentirci' is an idiomatic expression meaning 'to be able to hear'. 'Ci sentiamo' means 'we can hear'.

complete_sentence: Quanto tempo ci vuole per arrivare?
question_text: Quanto tempo ___ vuole per arrivare?
english_translation: How much time does it take to get there?
explanation: RULE: The verb 'volerci' means 'to take' or 'to require' (time). It is impersonal; 'ci vuole' for singular nouns and 'ci vogliono' for plural.

complete_sentence: A Roma ci sono molti musei.
question_text: A Roma ___ sono molti musei.
english_translation: In Rome there are many museums.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'esserci' means 'there is' ('c'è') or 'there are' ('ci sono').

complete_sentence: Dove abiti? Ci abito in centro.
question_text: Dove abiti? ___ abito in centro.
english_translation: Where do you live? I live downtown.
explanation: RULE: The particle 'ci' can be used to replace a previously mentioned location, meaning 'there'. Here it replaces 'a [city name]'.

complete_sentence: Che ore sono?
question_text: Che ore ___?
english_translation: What time is it?
explanation: RULE: The standard question to ask for the time is 'Che ore sono?'.

complete_sentence: È l' una e mezza.
question_text: È ___ una e mezza.
english_translation: It's one thirty.
explanation: RULE: When telling the time for one o'clock, the phrase 'È l'una' is used.

complete_sentence: Sono le tre e un quarto.
question_text: Sono ___ tre e un quarto.
english_translation: It's three fifteen.
explanation: RULE: For any hour after one o'clock, the structure 'Sono le + [hour]' is used.

complete_sentence: Sono le nove meno venti.
question_text: Sono le nove ___ venti.
english_translation: It's twenty to nine.
explanation: RULE: To express minutes before the next hour, 'meno' is used. 'Le nove meno venti' literally means 'nine minus twenty'.

complete_sentence: Ci vediamo a mezzogiorno.
question_text: Ci vediamo ___ mezzogiorno.
english_translation: See you at noon.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'a' is used with 'mezzogiorno' (noon) and 'mezzanotte' (midnight).

complete_sentence: Il negozio apre alle nove.
question_text: Il negozio apre ___ nove.
english_translation: The store opens at nine.
explanation: RULE: To state a specific time on the clock, the preposition 'alle' is used.

complete_sentence: Quella persona è molto simpatica
question_text: ___ persona è molto simpatica
english_translation: That person is very nice.
explanation: RULE: The demonstrative adjective 'quello' changes form like the definite article. Before 'persona' (feminine, starts with consonant), it becomes 'Quella'.

complete_sentence: Questi ragazzi sono i miei amici
question_text: ___ ragazzi sono i miei amici
english_translation: These boys are my friends.
explanation: RULE: 'Questo' means 'this/these'. It must agree with the noun. For the masculine plural 'ragazzi', the form is 'Questi'.

complete_sentence: Questa macchina è di mio padre
question_text: ___ macchina è di mio padre
english_translation: This car is my father's.
explanation: RULE: 'Questo' means 'this/these'. For the feminine singular noun 'macchina', the correct form is 'Questa'.

complete_sentence: Quelle case sono molto vecchie
question_text: ___ case sono molto vecchie
english_translation: Those houses are very old.
explanation: RULE: 'Quello' means 'that/those'. For the feminine plural noun 'case', the correct form is 'Quelle'.

complete_sentence: Questo libro è il mio preferito
question_text: ___ libro è il mio preferito
english_translation: This is my favorite book.
explanation: RULE: 'Questo' means 'this/these'. For the masculine singular noun 'libro', the correct form is 'Questo'.

complete_sentence: Quelle bambine giocano nel parco
question_text: ___ bambine giocano nel parco
english_translation: Those girls play in the park.
explanation: RULE: 'Quello' means 'that/those'. For the feminine plural noun 'bambine', the correct form is 'Quelle'.

complete_sentence: I tuoi genitori sono molto giovani
question_text: I ___ genitori sono molto giovani
english_translation: Your parents are very young.
explanation: RULE: Possessive adjectives agree with the possessed noun. For 'genitori' (masculine plural), the 'tu' form is 'tuoi'. The article 'i' is required.

complete_sentence: La sua amica è francese
question_text: La ___ amica è francese
english_translation: Her friend is French.
explanation: RULE: The possessive for 'her' is 'suo/sua/suoi/sue'. It must agree with the possessed noun 'amica' (feminine singular), making it 'sua'.

complete_sentence: Il nostro cane è molto intelligente
question_text: Il ___ cane è molto intelligente
english_translation: Our dog is very intelligent.
explanation: RULE: The possessive for 'our' is 'nostro/a/i/e'. It agrees with 'cane' (masculine singular), so it is 'nostro'.

complete_sentence: Le loro sorelle abitano a Milano
question_text: Le ___ sorelle abitano a Milano
english_translation: Their sisters live in Milan.
explanation: RULE: The possessive adjective 'loro' (their) is invariable; it does not change for gender or number.

complete_sentence: La vostra casa è molto grande
question_text: La ___ casa è molto grande
english_translation: Your house is very big.
explanation: RULE: The possessive for 'your' (plural 'voi') is 'vostro/a/i/e'. It agrees with 'casa' (feminine singular), so it is 'vostra'.

complete_sentence: I miei figli sono ancora piccoli
question_text: I ___ figli sono ancora piccoli
english_translation: My children are still young.
explanation: RULE: The possessive for 'my' is 'mio/mia/miei/mie'. It agrees with 'figli' (masculine plural), so it is 'miei'.

complete_sentence: Mio fratello è medico
question_text: Mio ___ è medico
english_translation: My brother is a doctor.
explanation: RULE: The definite article is usually omitted before singular, unmodified family members. 'Mio fratello' is correct.

complete_sentence: Tua madre cucina molto bene
question_text: Tua ___ cucina molto bene
english_translation: Your mother cooks very well.
explanation: RULE: The definite article is omitted before singular family nouns like 'madre'. 'Tua madre' is correct.

complete_sentence: Ho appena comprato una macchina nuova
question_text: Ho ___ comprato una macchina nuova
english_translation: I just bought a new car.
explanation: RULE: The adverb 'appena' means 'just' (in the recent past) and is placed between the auxiliary verb and the past participle.

complete_sentence: È già partito per le vacanze
question_text: È ___ partito per le vacanze
english_translation: He already left for vacation.
explanation: RULE: The adverb 'già' means 'already' and is typically placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

complete_sentence: Non ha ancora finito i compiti
question_text: Non ha ___ finito i compiti
english_translation: He hasn't finished his homework yet.
explanation: RULE: In a negative sentence, 'ancora' means 'yet' or 'still'. 'Non ha ancora finito' means 'He has not yet finished'.

complete_sentence: Da una settimana studio italiano
question_text: ___ una settimana studio italiano
english_translation: I've been studying Italian for a week.
explanation: RULE: 'Da' is used with a time expression to indicate an action that began in the past and is still ongoing.

complete_sentence: Ho lavorato per otto ore
question_text: Ho lavorato ___ otto ore
english_translation: I worked for eight hours.
explanation: RULE: 'Per' is used to indicate the total duration of a completed past action.

complete_sentence: Torno a casa fra poco.
question_text: Torno a casa ___ poco.
english_translation: I'm going home soon.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'fra poco' (or 'tra poco') means 'in a little while' or 'soon'.

complete_sentence: Ho finito il lavoro in due ore.
question_text: Ho finito il lavoro ___ due ore.
english_translation: I finished the work in two hours.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'in' can be used to express the amount of time it took to complete an action.

complete_sentence: In inverno fa sempre freddo.
question_text: ___ inverno fa sempre freddo.
english_translation: In winter it's always cold.
explanation: RULE: The preposition 'in' is used before seasons, such as 'in inverno'.

complete_sentence: Da bambino ero molto timido.
question_text: ___ bambino ero molto timido.
english_translation: As a child I was very shy.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'Da bambino' is a common way to say 'As a child' when reminiscing.

complete_sentence: Una volta vivevo con i miei nonni.
question_text: Una volta ___ con i miei nonni.
english_translation: I used to live with my grandparents.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a continued situation or habit in the past ('used to live'). The 'io' form is 'vivevo'.

complete_sentence: Nel duemiladieci ho comprato la mia prima macchina.
question_text: Nel duemiladieci ___ la mia prima macchina.
english_translation: In 2010 I bought my first car.
explanation: RULE: The 'passato prossimo' is used for a single, completed event at a specific time in the past ('Nel 2010').

complete_sentence: Ogni estate andavo al mare con la famiglia.
question_text: Ogni estate ___ al mare con la famiglia.
english_translation: Every summer I went to the beach with my family.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used for repeated, habitual actions in the past ('Every summer'). The 'io' form is 'andavo'.

complete_sentence: A scuola ero sempre bravo in matematica.
question_text: A scuola ___ sempre bravo in matematica.
english_translation: At school I was always good at math.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a past state or characteristic. The 'io' form of 'essere' is 'ero'.

complete_sentence: Due anni fa ho preso il diploma.
question_text: Due anni fa ___ il diploma.
english_translation: Two years ago I got my diploma.
explanation: RULE: 'Due anni fa' indicates a specific point in the past, so the 'passato prossimo' is required. The form is 'ho preso'.

complete_sentence: Quando avevo sedici anni ho preso la patente.
question_text: Quando avevo sedici anni ___ la patente.
english_translation: When I was 16 I got my license.
explanation: RULE: This refers to a single, completed event in the past, requiring the 'passato prossimo'. The form is 'ho preso'.

complete_sentence: Durante l'università vivevo in una casa con amici.
question_text: Durante l'università ___ in una casa con amici.
english_translation: During university I lived in a house with friends.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used to describe a situation that continued for a period of time in the past. The 'io' form is 'vivevo'.

complete_sentence: Paolo ha gli occhi azzurri e i capelli castani.
question_text: Paolo ha gli occhi azzuri e i capelli ___.
english_translation: Paolo has blue eyes and brown hair.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree in gender and number. 'Occhi' and 'capelli' are both masculine plural, so the adjectives must be 'azzurri' and 'castani'.

complete_sentence: La mia amica è molto gentile e sempre sorridente.
question_text: La mia amica è molto gentile e sempre ___.
english_translation: My friend is very kind and always smiling.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree with the noun 'amica' (feminine singular). 'sorridente' has the same form for both masculine and feminine singular.

complete_sentence: Mio nonno è un uomo anziano con una barba bianca.
question_text: Mio nonno è un uomo ___ con una barba bianca.
english_translation: My grandfather is an elderly man with a white beard.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree with the nouns they describe: 'uomo' is masculine singular ('anziano').

complete_sentence: Le mie sorelle sono alte e molto ___.
question_text: Le mie sorelle sono alte e molto ___.
english_translation: My sisters are tall and very athletic.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree with the noun 'sorelle' (feminine plural), so the form must be 'sportive'.

complete_sentence: Il professore è severo ma molto giusto.
question_text: Il professore è severo ma molto ___.
english_translation: The professor is strict but very fair.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree with the noun 'professore' (masculine singular), so the forms is 'severo'.

complete_sentence: Questa ragazza ha i capelli ricci e la pelle scura.
question_text: Questa ragazza ha i capelli ___ e la pelle scura.
english_translation: This girl has curly hair and dark skin.
explanation: RULE: Adjectives must agree with the nouns: 'capelli' is masculine plural ('ricci'), and 'pelle' is feminine singular ('scura').

complete_sentence: Mi fa male la schiena quando studio troppo.
question_text: Mi fa male ___ quando studio troppo.
english_translation: My back hurts when I study too much.
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'back' is 'la schiena' (feminine singular).

complete_sentence: Devo prendere un sciroppo per la tosse.
question_text: Devo prendere un ___ per la tosse.
english_translation: I need to take cough medicine.
explanation: RULE: 'Sciroppo' is the specific word for 'syrup', used in 'sciroppo per la tosse' (cough syrup).

complete_sentence: Mi sono fatto male al il piede mentre correvo.
question_text: Mi sono ___ il piede mentre correvo.
english_translation: I hurt my foot while running.
explanation: RULE: The reflexive expression 'farsi male a' means 'to hurt oneself on/in a body part'. The form is 'mi sono fatto male al piede'.

complete_sentence: Ho la nausea perché ho mangiato troppo.
question_text: Ho la ___ perché ho mangiato troppo.
english_translation: I have a stomachache because I ate too much.
explanation: RULE: 'Nausea' is the feeling of being sick to your stomach.

complete_sentence: Il dottore mi ha prescritto delle vitamine.
question_text: Il dottore mi ha ___ delle vitamine.
english_translation: The doctor prescribed me some vitamins.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'prescrivere' means 'to prescribe'. Its past participle is 'prescritto'.

complete_sentence: Ho bisogno di riposarmi.
question_text: Ho bisogno di ___.
english_translation: I need to rest.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'riposarsi' (to rest) is reflexive. After 'bisogno di', the infinitive is used, and the pronoun 'mi' attaches to the end: 'riposarmi'.

complete_sentence: Vorrei provare questi pantaloni prima di comprarli.
question_text: Vorrei ___ questi pantaloni prima di comprarli.
english_translation: I'd like to try on these pants before buying them.
explanation: RULE: In a shopping context, 'provare' means 'to try on' clothes.

complete_sentence: Questo numero è troppo piccolo per me
question_text: Questo ___ è troppo piccolo per me
english_translation: This size is too small for me.
explanation: RULE: For shoes, the word for 'size' is 'numero'. 'taglia' also works but is used left often, but importantly this phrase starts with 'Questo' not 'Questa'.

complete_sentence: Quanto costano questi stivali?
question_text: Quanto ___ questi stivali?
english_translation: How much do these boots cost?
explanation: RULE: The verb 'costare' (to cost) must agree with the subject 'questi stivali' (plural), so the correct form is 'costano'.

complete_sentence: Posso pagare con la carta di credito?
question_text: Posso pagare ___ carta di credito?
english_translation: Can I pay with a credit card?
explanation: RULE: The correct prepositional phrase for 'with a credit card' is 'con la carta di credito'.

complete_sentence: C'è uno sconto su questo articolo?
question_text: C'è uno ___ su questo articolo?
english_translation: Is there a discount on this item?
explanation: RULE: The word for a 'discount' in a shop is 'sconto'.

complete_sentence: Vorrei cambiare questa maglietta perché è rotta
question_text: Vorrei cambiare questa ___ perché è rotta
english_translation: I'd like to exchange this t-shirt because it's broken.
explanation: RULE: The word for 't-shirt' is 'maglietta' (feminine singular).

complete_sentence: Per favore, un piatto di spaghetti alla carbonara.
question_text: Per favore, un ___ di spaghetti alla carbonara.
english_translation: Please, a plate of spaghetti carbonara.
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'un piatto di...' means 'a plate of...'.

complete_sentence: Cosa consiglia come dolce?
question_text: Cosa ___ come dolce?
english_translation: What do you recommend for dessert?
explanation: RULE: 'Consigliare' means 'to recommend'. When addressing a waiter formally ('Lei'), the correct form is 'consiglia'.

complete_sentence: La mancia è inclusa nel prezzo?
question_text: La ___ è inclusa nel prezzo?
english_translation: Is the tip included in the price?
explanation: RULE: The Italian word for 'tip' (gratuity) is 'mancia'.

complete_sentence: Scusi, questo piatto è troppo salato.
question_text: Scusi, questo ___ è troppo salato.
english_translation: Excuse me, this dish is too salty.
explanation: RULE: 'Piatto' can mean both 'plate' and 'dish' (a prepared food item).

complete_sentence: Mi piace molto la cucina italiana.
question_text: Mi piace molto la ___ italiana.
english_translation: I really like Italian cuisine.
explanation: RULE: The word 'cucina' means 'kitchen' or 'cuisine'.

complete_sentence: Ci vediamo stasera per andare al cinema.
question_text: Ci vediamo ___ per andare al cinema.
english_translation: Let's meet tonight to go to the movies.
explanation: RULE: The adverb of time 'stasera' means 'tonight' or 'this evening'.

complete_sentence: Che ne dici di fare una passeggiata?
question_text: Che ne dici di ___ una passeggiata?
english_translation: What do you think about taking a walk?
explanation: RULE: The suggestion phrase 'Che ne dici di...?' is followed by an infinitive. 'Fare una passeggiata' means 'to take a walk'.

complete_sentence: Ci incontriamo davanti al teatro?
question_text: ___ incontriamo davanti al teatro?
english_translation: Shall we meet in front of the theater?
explanation: RULE: The reciprocal verb 'incontrarsi' (to meet each other) uses the pronoun 'ci' for the 'noi' form: 'ci incontriamo'.

complete_sentence: Ho un appuntamento dal dentista alle tre.
question_text: Ho un ___ dal dentista alle tre.
english_translation: I have a dentist appointment at three.
explanation: RULE: The word for a scheduled meeting or 'appointment' is 'appuntamento'.

complete_sentence: Sei libero sabato pomeriggio?
question_text: Sei ___ sabato pomeriggio?
english_translation: Are you free Saturday afternoon?
explanation: RULE: The expression 'essere libero' means 'to be free' (not busy).

complete_sentence: Possiamo rimandare a domani?
question_text: ___ rimandare a domani?
english_translation: Can we postpone until tomorrow?
explanation: RULE: To ask 'Can we...?', the verb 'potere' is used. The 'noi' form is 'Possiamo'.

complete_sentence: Ti va di venire insieme?
question_text: Ti va di ___ insieme?
english_translation: Do you feel like coming with me?
explanation: RULE: The suggestion phrase 'Ti va di...?' must be followed by a verb in the infinitive form, such as 'venire'. 'venire insieme' is a common expression, equivalent to 'venire con me.'

complete_sentence: Dopo cena mi rilasso sempre un po'.
question_text: Dopo cena ___ sempre un po'.
english_translation: After dinner I always relax a bit.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'rilassarsi' (to relax) is reflexive. The first-person singular form is 'mi rilasso'.

complete_sentence: Prima di andare al lavoro leggo il giornale.
question_text: Prima di andare al lavoro ___ il giornale.
english_translation: Before going to work I read the newspaper.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'leggere' means 'to read'. The first-person singular present tense is 'leggo'.

complete_sentence: Tutte le sere guardo un po' di televisione.
question_text: Tutte le sere ___ un po' di televisione.
english_translation: Every evening I watch a bit of television.
explanation: RULE: The verb 'guardare' means 'to watch'. The 'io' form is 'guardo'.

complete_sentence: Il mio sport preferito è il tennis.
question_text: Il mio ___ preferito è il tennis.
english_translation: My favorite sport is tennis.
explanation: RULE: 'Sport' is the correct noun for an athletic activity like tennis.

complete_sentence: Nel tempo libero mi piace dipingere.
question_text: Nel tempo libero mi piace ___.
english_translation: In my free time I like painting.
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'mi piace' must be followed by an infinitive verb, like 'dipingere' (to paint).

complete_sentence: So suonare la chitarra e il violino.
question_text: So suonare la ___ e il violino.
english_translation: I can play guitar and violin.
explanation: RULE: 'Chitarra' is the Italian word for 'guitar'.

complete_sentence: Gioco a calcio ogni domenica.
question_text: Gioco a ___ ogni domenica.
english_translation: I play soccer every Sunday.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'giocare a calcio' means 'to play soccer'.

complete_sentence: Mi piace andare nei musei.
question_text: Mi piace ___ nei musei.
english_translation: I like going to museums.
explanation: RULE: The phrase 'mi piace' must be followed by an infinitive verb, such as 'andare' (to go).

complete_sentence: Faccio footing per mantenermi in forma.
question_text: Faccio ___ per mantenermi in forma.
english_translation: I jog to stay in shape.
explanation: RULE: The expression 'fare footing' (or 'fare jogging') is commonly used to mean 'to go jogging'.

complete_sentence: Il mio papà è ingegnere.
question_text: Il mio ___ è ingegnere.
english_translation: My father is an engineer.
explanation: RULE: 'Papà' is a common, slightly informal word for 'father'.

complete_sentence: Ho due fratelli più piccoli di me.
question_text: Ho due ___ più piccoli di me.
english_translation: I have two brothers younger than me.
explanation: RULE: 'Fratelli' is the masculine plural noun for 'brothers'.

complete_sentence: I miei genitori sono sposati da trent'anni.
question_text: I miei ___ sono sposati da trent'anni.
english_translation: My parents have been married for 30 years.
explanation: RULE: 'Genitori' is the Italian word for 'parents'.

complete_sentence: Mio cugino ha quindici anni.
question_text: Mio ___ ha quindici anni.
english_translation: My cousin is 15 years old.
explanation: RULE: 'Cugino' is the word for a male 'cousin'.

complete_sentence: La moglie di mio fratello è molto simpatica.
question_text: La ___ di mio fratello è molto simpatica.
english_translation: My brother's wife is very nice.
explanation: RULE: 'Moglie' is the Italian word for 'wife'.

complete_sentence: I miei nonni abitano in campagna.
question_text: I miei ___ abitano in campagna.
english_translation: My grandparents live in the countryside.
explanation: RULE: 'Nonni' is the Italian word for 'grandparents'.

complete_sentence: Lavoro in una ditta di informatica.
question_text: Lavoro in una ___ di informatica.
english_translation: I work for a computer company.
explanation: RULE: 'Ditta' is a word for 'company' or 'firm'.

complete_sentence: Il mio turno inizia alle nove.
question_text: Il mio ___ inizia alle nove.
english_translation: My work shift starts at 9.
explanation: RULE: 'Turno di lavoro' means 'work shift'. 'Turno' is sufficient in this context.

complete_sentence: Ho una riunione di lavoro importante.
question_text: Ho una ___ di lavoro importante.
english_translation: I have an important work meeting.
explanation: RULE: 'Riunione' is the word for 'meeting'.

complete_sentence: Prendo la pausa pranzo ogni giorno a mezzogiorno.
question_text: Prendo ___ ogni giorno a mezzogiorno.
english_translation: I take my lunch break every day at noon.
explanation: RULE: The specific term for 'lunch break' is 'pausa pranzo'.

complete_sentence: Il mio capo mi dà sempre molto lavoro.
question_text: Il mio ___ mi dà sempre molto lavoro.
english_translation: My boss always gives me a lot of work.
explanation: RULE: 'Capo' is the Italian word for 'boss'.

complete_sentence: Devo fare una presentazione domani.
question_text: Devo ___ una presentazione domani.
english_translation: I have to give a presentation tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: The common expression for 'to give a presentation' is 'fare una presentazione'.

complete_sentence: Lavoro a tempo pieno.
question_text: Lavoro ___ tempo pieno.
english_translation: I work full-time.
explanation: RULE: The fixed expression for 'full-time' is 'a tempo pieno'.

complete_sentence: Lui ha comprato al mercato ieri.
question_text: Lui ___ al mercato ieri. (comprare)
english_translation: He bought at the market yesterday.
explanation: RULE: For a completed action in the past, 'passato prossimo' is used. 'Comprare' is a transitive verb that uses 'avere'. The 'lui' form is 'ha comprato'.

complete_sentence: Se fossi ricco, viaggerei in tutto il mondo.
question_text: Se fossi ricco, ___ in tutto il mondo. (viaggiare)
english_translation: If I were rich, I would travel around the world.
explanation: RULE: To express a hypothetical situation, the 'condizionale' is used. The 'io' conditional form of 'viaggiare' is 'viaggerei'.

complete_sentence: Noi vogliamo imparare l’italiano.
question_text: Noi ___ imparare l’italiano. (volere)
english_translation: We want to learn Italian.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'volere' expresses desire. The first-person plural ('noi') present tense form is 'vogliamo'.

complete_sentence: Questa borsa è più cara di quella.
question_text: Questa borsa è ___ cara di quella.
english_translation: This bag is more expensive than that one.
explanation: RULE: To make a comparison of superiority (more expensive), 'più' is used before the adjective.

complete_sentence: È il più bel film che abbia mai visto.
question_text: È il ___ bel film che abbia mai visto.
english_translation: It’s the most beautiful movie I’ve ever seen.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative is formed with 'il/la + più + [adjective]'. For 'film' (masculine), it is 'il più bel film'.

complete_sentence: Tu sai parlare francese?
question_text: Tu ___ parlare francese? (sapere)
english_translation: Do you know how to speak French?
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'sapere' expresses a learned skill. The second-person singular ('tu') present tense form is 'sai'.

complete_sentence: Ieri sera ho guardato un film interessante.
question_text: Ieri sera ___ un film interessante. (guardare)
english_translation: Last night I watched an interesting movie.
explanation: RULE: For a specific completed action ('ieri sera'), the 'passato prossimo' is used. 'Guardare' uses 'avere', so the form is 'ho guardato'.

complete_sentence: Ogni mattina mi alzo alle sei
question_text: Ogni mattina ___ alle sei
english_translation: Every morning I get up at six.
explanation: RULE: For a daily routine, the present indicative is used. 'Alzarsi' is a reflexive verb, and the 'io' form is 'mi alzo'.

complete_sentence: Dove stai andando?
question_text: ___ stai andando?
english_translation: Where are you going?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Dove' is used to ask about location ('where').

complete_sentence: Non sono mai stato in Italia.
question_text: Non ___ mai stato in Italia. (essere)
english_translation: I have never been to Italy.
explanation: RULE: In the 'passato prossimo', the verb 'essere' uses 'essere' as its auxiliary. The adverb 'mai' (never) goes between the auxiliary and participle. The form for a male speaker is 'sono mai stato'.

complete_sentence: Domani avrò un esame importante
question_text: Domani ___ un esame importante
english_translation: Tomorrow I will have an important exam.
explanation: RULE: To talk about a future event, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'io' future form of the irregular verb 'avere' is 'avrò'.

complete_sentence: Se potessi, vivrei in montagna.
question_text: Se potessi, ___ in montagna. (vivere)
english_translation: If I could, I would live in the mountains.
explanation: RULE: To express a hypothetical situation, the 'condizionale' is used. The 'io' conditional form of 'vivere' is 'vivrei'.

complete_sentence: Loro hanno preparato la cena ieri sera.
question_text: Loro ___ la cena ieri sera. (preparare)
english_translation: They prepared dinner last night.
explanation: RULE: For a specific past action ('ieri sera'), the 'passato prossimo' is used. 'Preparare' uses 'avere', and the 'loro' form is 'hanno preparato'.

complete_sentence: Chi è il tuo migliore amico?
question_text: ___ è il tuo migliore amico?
english_translation: Who is your best friend?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Chi' is used to ask about a person ('who').

complete_sentence: Quando ero giovane, studiavo molto.
question_text: Quando ero giovane, ___ molto. (studiare)
english_translation: When I was young, I studied a lot.
explanation: RULE: To describe a habitual action or general situation in the past, the 'imperfetto' is used. The 'io' form is 'studiavo'.

complete_sentence: Noi andiamo al mare ogni estate.
question_text: Noi ___ al mare ogni estate. (andare)
english_translation: We go to the beach every summer.
explanation: RULE: For a habitual action ('every summer'), the present indicative is used. The 'noi' form of 'andare' is 'andiamo'.

complete_sentence: Questo è il più bel quadro della galleria.
question_text: Questo è il ___ bel quadro della galleria.
english_translation: This is the most beautiful painting in the gallery.
explanation: RULE: The relative superlative is formed with 'il/la + più + [adjective]'. For 'quadro' (masculine), it is 'il più bel quadro'.

complete_sentence: Ieri sono restato tutta la giornata a casa.
question_text: Ieri ___ tutta la giornata a casa. (restare)
english_translation: Yesterday I stayed home all day.
explanation: RULE: 'Restare' is a verb of state that uses 'essere' in the 'passato prossimo'. For a male speaker, the 'io' form is 'sono restato'.

complete_sentence: Che cosa fai per lavoro?
question_text: ___ fai per lavoro?
english_translation: What do you do for a living?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative phrase 'Che cosa' is used to ask about things or activities ('what').

complete_sentence: Se fossi in te, farei più attenzione.
question_text: Se fossi in te, ___ più attenzione. (fare)
english_translation: If I were you, I would pay more attention.
explanation: RULE: The 'condizionale' is used for giving advice in a hypothetical situation. The 'io' conditional form of 'fare' is 'farei'.

complete_sentence: Tu sei sempre così gentile.
question_text: Tu ___ sempre così gentile. (essere)
english_translation: You are always so kind.
explanation: RULE: To describe a characteristic in the present, the indicative is used. The 'tu' form of 'essere' is 'sei'.

complete_sentence: La settimana prossima viaggerò a Roma
question_text: La settimana prossima ___ a Roma
english_translation: Next week I will travel to Rome.
explanation: RULE: For a future plan, the 'futuro semplice' is used. The 'io' future form of 'viaggiare' is 'viaggerò'.

complete_sentence: Questa città è più grande di quella.
question_text: Questa città è ___ grande di quella.
english_translation: This city is bigger than that one.
explanation: RULE: To form a comparative of superiority (bigger than), 'più' is used.

complete_sentence: Io devo studiare stasera.
question_text: Io ___ studiare stasera.
english_translation: I have to study tonight.
explanation: RULE: The modal verb 'dovere' expresses obligation. The 'io' present tense form is 'devo'.

complete_sentence: Da bambino, andavo spesso al parco.
question_text: Da bambino, ___ spesso al parco. (andare)
english_translation: As a child, I often went to the park.
explanation: RULE: The 'imperfetto' is used for repeated past actions. The 'io' imperfetto form of 'andare' is 'andavo'.

complete_sentence: Lui ha ricevuto un bel regalo per il compleanno.
question_text: Lui ___ un bel regalo per il compleanno. (ricevere)
english_translation: He received a nice gift for his birthday.
explanation: RULE: 'Passato prossimo' is used for a single completed action. 'Ricevere' uses 'avere', so the 'lui' form is 'ha ricevuto'.

complete_sentence: Qual' è la tua città preferita?
question_text: ___ è la tua città preferita?
english_translation: Which is your favorite city?
explanation: RULE: The interrogative word 'Quale' is used to ask for a choice ('which').

explanation: RULE: Rain on roof produces sound, so 'sentire' means 'to hear'. 'Cadere' (falling) on roof creates noise. Context determines auditory meaning.

complete_sentence: Non sento nessun sapore, ho il raffreddore.
question_text: Non sento nessun ___, ho il raffreddore.
english_translation: I can't taste anything, I have a cold.
explanation: RULE: 'Sapore' (taste/flavor) with 'sentire' means 'to taste'. Having a cold affects taste, confirming the gustatory meaning of 'sentire' here.

complete_sentence: Fammi sentire la tua mano.
question_text: Write: Let me feel your hand.
english_translation: Fammi sentire la tua mano.
alternate_correct_responses: Fammi toccare la tua mano,Lasciami sentire la tua mano
explanation: RULE: Physical contact with body parts uses 'sentire' for 'to feel/touch'. 'Mano' (hand) in this context implies checking temperature or texture through touch.

complete_sentence: Senti un po' questa storia!
question_text: Senti un po' questa ___!
english_translation: Listen to this story!
explanation: RULE: 'Storia' (story) is something you hear/listen to. 'Senti un po'' is a common expression meaning 'listen here' or 'hear this' when introducing information.

complete_sentence: Si sente male da stamattina.
question_text: Si sente ___ da stamattina.
english_translation: She has been feeling sick since this morning.
explanation: RULE: 'Sentirsi male/bene' is an idiom meaning 'to feel sick/well'. Reflexive 'sentirsi' + 'male' describes health condition, not hearing or smelling.

complete_sentence: Ho sentito dire che parti domani.
question_text: Ho sentito ___ che parti domani.
english_translation: I heard (someone say) that you're leaving tomorrow.
explanation: RULE: 'Sentire dire' is a fixed expression meaning 'to hear (it said)'. This refers to hearing information or rumors, always uses 'dire' after 'sentito'.

complete_sentence: Sento le campane della chiesa.
question_text: Sento le ___ della chiesa.
english_translation: I hear the church bells.
explanation: RULE: 'Campane' (bells) produce sound, making 'sentire' mean 'to hear'. Church bells ringing is an auditory experience, not smell or touch.

complete_sentence: Senti se il latte è ancora caldo.
question_text: Write: Feel if the milk is still warm.
english_translation: Senti se il latte è ancora caldo.
alternate_correct_responses: Tocca se il latte è ancora caldo,Controlla se il latte è ancora caldo
option_a: Senti se il latte è ancora caldo
option_b: Ascolta se il latte è ancora caldo
option_c: Odora se il latte è ancora caldo
option_d: Guarda se il latte è ancora caldo
explanation: RULE: Checking temperature ('caldo') of liquids uses 'sentire' for 'to feel'. This is about testing physical warmth through touch, not hearing or smelling.

complete_sentence: Non si sentono da anni.
question_text: Non si ___ da anni.
english_translation: They haven't heard from each other in years.
explanation: RULE: Reciprocal 'sentirsi' means 'to hear from each other' in communication context. 'Da anni' (for years) indicates contact through phone/messages.

complete_sentence: Sento che sta per piovere.
question_text: Write: I feel it's about to rain.
english_translation: Sento che sta per piovere.
alternate_correct_responses: Sento che pioverà,Mi sembra che sta per piovere
explanation: RULE: 'Sentire che' + future event means 'to feel/sense' (intuition). This is about sensing or having a feeling something will happen, not literal hearing or smelling.

complete_sentence: Senti questo vino se sa di tappo.
question_text: Senti questo vino se sa di ___.
english_translation: Taste this wine to see if it tastes corked.
explanation: RULE: Wine tasting context with 'sapere di' (to taste of) makes 'sentire' mean 'to taste'. 'Sa di tappo' is wine terminology for cork taint.

complete_sentence: Si sente solo in questa città.
question_text: Si sente ___ in questa città.
english_translation: He feels lonely in this city.
explanation: RULE: 'Sentirsi' + emotional adjective ('solo' = lonely) expresses emotional state. This reflexive use describes feelings, not physical sensations.

complete_sentence: Hai sentito l'ultima notizia?
question_text: Hai sentito l'ultima ___?
english_translation: Have you heard the latest news?
explanation: RULE: 'Notizia' (news) is information you hear. 'L'ultima notizia' (latest news) confirms 'sentire' means 'to hear' about information or events.

complete_sentence: Sento il cuore che batte forte.
question_text: Sento il cuore che ___ forte.
english_translation: I feel my heart beating hard.
explanation: RULE: Heartbeat can be both heard and felt. 'Battere' (to beat) with 'cuore' (heart) uses 'sentire' for physical sensation of feeling the heartbeat.

complete_sentence: Non mi sento di uscire stasera.
question_text: Write: I don't feel like going out tonight.
english_translation: Non mi sento di uscire stasera.
alternate_correct_responses: Non ho voglia di uscire stasera,Non me la sento di uscire stasera
option_a: Non mi sento di uscire stasera
option_b: Non mi ascolto di uscire stasera
option_c: Non mi odoro di uscire stasera
option_d: Non mi guardo di uscire stasera
explanation: RULE: 'Sentirsi di' + infinitive is an idiom meaning 'to feel like/up to' doing something. Expresses willingness or energy for an activity.

complete_sentence: Vado al supermercato ogni sabato.
question_text: Vado ___ supermercato ogni sabato.
english_translation: I go to the supermarket every Saturday.
explanation: The preposition 'a' contracts with the masculine singular article 'il' to form 'al' (a + il = al).

complete_sentence: Compro il pane e lo mangio fresco.
question_text: Compro il pane e ___ mangio fresco.
english_translation: I buy bread and eat it fresh.
explanation: The direct object pronoun 'lo' replaces the masculine singular noun 'il pane'.

complete_sentence: La mamma ci chiama per cena.
question_text: La mamma ___ chiama per cena.
english_translation: Mom calls us for dinner.
explanation: The direct object pronoun 'ci' means 'us' and is placed before the conjugated verb.

complete_sentence: Compro il biglietto dell'autobus in tabaccheria.
question_text: Compro il biglietto ___ in tabaccheria.
english_translation: I buy the bus ticket at the tobacco shop.
explanation: Context indicates buying a bus ticket, so 'dell'autobus' (of the bus) is the logical choice.

complete_sentence: Ho la febbre e resto a casa.
question_text: Ho la febbre e ___ a casa.
english_translation: I have a fever and stay home.
explanation: When sick with fever, the logical action is 'resto' (I stay) at home rather than going out.

complete_sentence: Da piccola mangiavo sempre la pasta.
question_text: Da piccola ___ sempre la pasta.
english_translation: When I was little, I always ate pasta.
explanation: The imperfetto 'mangiavo' expresses a habitual action in the past, indicated by 'sempre' (always).

complete_sentence: Hai dei biscotti? Ne voglio due.
question_text: Hai dei biscotti? ___ voglio due.
english_translation: Do you have cookies? I want two of them.
explanation: The particle 'ne' means 'of them/some' and replaces a partitive expression with an indefinite quantity.

complete_sentence: Le ragazze sono arrivate in ritardo.
question_text: Le ragazze ___ in ritardo.
english_translation: The girls arrived late.
explanation: The verb 'arrivare' uses auxiliary 'essere' in passato prossimo, and the past participle agrees with the feminine plural subject.

complete_sentence: Marco compra i libri. Li compra in libreria.
question_text: Marco compra i libri. ___ compra in libreria.
english_translation: Marco buys the books. He buys them at the bookstore.
explanation: The direct object pronoun 'li' replaces 'i libri' (masculine plural). Direct object pronouns agree in gender and number with the noun they replace.

complete_sentence: Vedi Maria? Sì, la vedo.
question_text: Vedi Maria? Sì, ___ vedo.
english_translation: Do you see Maria? Yes, I see her.
explanation: The direct object pronoun 'la' replaces 'Maria' (feminine singular). The pronoun precedes the conjugated verb.

complete_sentence: Per andare a Roma prendo il treno.
question_text: Per andare a Roma prendo ___ treno.
english_translation: To go to Rome I take the train.
explanation: The noun 'treno' is masculine singular, so it takes the definite article 'il'.

complete_sentence: Ho mal di testa.
question_text: Ho mal di ___.
english_translation: I have a headache.
explanation: The expression 'mal di testa' (headache) uses the singular form 'testa' (head). This is a fixed expression in Italian.

complete_sentence: Maria è rimasta a casa ieri sera.
question_text: Maria è ___ a casa ieri sera.
english_translation: Maria stayed home last night.
explanation: The verb 'rimanere' uses 'essere' as auxiliary in passato prossimo. The past participle 'rimasta' agrees with the feminine subject 'Maria'.

complete_sentence: Ho bisogno delle chiavi per aprire la porta.
question_text: Ho bisogno ___ chiavi per aprire la porta.
english_translation: I need the keys to open the door.
explanation: The preposition 'di' combines with the article 'le' to form 'delle'. 'Avere bisogno di' (to need) requires the preposition 'di', which contracts with the definite article.

complete_sentence: Compri i biglietti? Sì, li compro subito.
question_text: Compri i biglietti? Sì, ___ compro subito.
english_translation: Are you buying the tickets? Yes, I'm buying them right away.
explanation: The masculine plural direct object pronoun 'li' replaces 'i biglietti' (the tickets). Direct object pronouns come before the conjugated verb.

complete_sentence: Per andare a Roma, prendiamo il treno delle otto.
question_text: Per andare a Roma, prendiamo il treno ___ otto.
english_translation: To go to Rome, we're taking the eight o'clock train.
explanation: When referring to scheduled transportation (trains, buses, planes), Italian uses 'di' + article to indicate the time: 'il treno delle otto' (the eight o'clock train).

complete_sentence: Le ragazze sono andate al cinema ieri sera.
question_text: Le ragazze ___ andate al cinema ieri sera.
english_translation: The girls went to the cinema last night.
explanation: The verb 'andare' (to go) uses 'essere' as its auxiliary in the passato prossimo. The past participle 'andate' agrees with the feminine plural subject 'le ragazze'.

complete_sentence: Il professore ci spiega sempre la lezione molto bene.
question_text: Il professore ___ spiega sempre la lezione molto bene.
english_translation: The teacher always explains the lesson to us very well.
explanation: The indirect object pronoun 'ci' (to us) is placed before the conjugated verb. The verb 'spiegare' takes an indirect object for the person receiving the explanation.

complete_sentence: Da bambina, andavo sempre in bicicletta con mia sorella.
question_text: Da bambina, ___ sempre in bicicletta con mia sorella.
english_translation: As a child, I always went by bicycle with my sister.
explanation: The imperfect tense 'andavo' is used to describe habitual actions in the past ('always went'). The phrase 'da bambina' signals past habitual action.

complete_sentence: Compro sempre della frutta fresca al mercato.
question_text: Compro sempre ___ frutta fresca al mercato.
english_translation: I always buy some fresh fruit at the market.
explanation: The partitive article 'della' (di + la) expresses 'some' with feminine singular uncountable nouns like fruit. It indicates a partial quantity.

complete_sentence: Ti piace questo libro?
question_text: ___ piace questo libro?
english_translation: Do you like this book?
explanation: Ti is the indirect object pronoun for 'to you' used with the verb piacere, which requires an indirect object.

complete_sentence: Mia nonna ci raccontava sempre delle favole.
question_text: Mia nonna ___ raccontava sempre delle favole.
english_translation: My grandmother always told us fairy tales.
explanation: Ci is the indirect object pronoun meaning 'to us', used when the action is directed toward the speakers.

complete_sentence: Gli telefono ogni sera.
question_text: ___ telefono ogni sera.
english_translation: I call him every evening.
explanation: Gli is the indirect object pronoun meaning 'to him'. Telefonare requires an indirect object (telefono a qualcuno).

complete_sentence: Vorrei del pane fresco.
question_text: Vorrei ___ pane fresco.
english_translation: I would like some fresh bread.
explanation: Del (di + il) is the partitive article meaning 'some' for masculine singular nouns beginning with consonants.

complete_sentence: Posso venire con te?
question_text: ___ venire con te?
english_translation: Can I come with you?
explanation: Posso (from potere) means 'can/may' and is followed by an infinitive verb (venire).

complete_sentence: Maria è più alta di sua sorella.
question_text: Maria è più alta ___ sua sorella.
english_translation: Maria is taller than her sister.
explanation: Use 'di' (than) in comparisons when comparing two nouns or pronouns with più/meno + adjective.

complete_sentence: Dopo pranzo faccio sempre una passeggiata nel parco.
question_text: Dopo pranzo ___ sempre una passeggiata nel parco.
english_translation: After lunch I always take a walk in the park.
explanation: Fare una passeggiata is the standard Italian expression meaning 'to take a walk'.

complete_sentence: Vai spesso al cinema? No, non ci vado mai.
question_text: Vai spesso al cinema? No, non ___ vado mai.
english_translation: Do you often go to the movies? No, I never go there.
explanation: Ci replaces al cinema (to the movies), functioning as a locative adverb meaning 'there'.

complete_sentence: Domani sera vado a cena da Marco.
question_text: Domani sera vado a cena ___ Marco.
english_translation: Tomorrow evening I'm going to dinner at Marco's place.
explanation: The preposition 'da' + person means 'at someone's place/home'. 'Da Marco' means 'at Marco's place'.

complete_sentence: Domani sera si divertiranno alla festa.
question_text: Domani sera ___ divertiranno alla festa.
english_translation: Tomorrow evening they will have fun at the party.
explanation: Si is the reflexive pronoun for third person plural used with reflexive verbs like divertirsi.

complete_sentence: Ho il raffreddore e starò a casa oggi.
question_text: Ho il raffreddore e ___ a casa oggi.
english_translation: I have a cold and I will stay home today.
explanation: Starò is the first person singular future tense of stare, used to express future states or actions.

complete_sentence: Conosci questo ristorante? Sì, ci mangio spesso.
question_text: Conosci questo ristorante? Sì, ___ mangio spesso.
english_translation: Do you know this restaurant? Yes, I eat there often.
explanation: Ci replaces the place already mentioned (questo ristorante), functioning as a locative adverb meaning 'there'.

complete_sentence: Ho comprato una torta per la festa.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ torta per la festa.
english_translation: I bought a cake for the party.
explanation: Una is the indefinite article for feminine singular nouns. It introduces a non-specific cake, not previously mentioned.

complete_sentence: Hai delle fragole fresche?
question_text: Hai ___ fragole fresche?
english_translation: Do you have some fresh strawberries?
explanation: Delle (di + le) is the partitive article for feminine plural nouns, meaning 'some' in questions and statements.

complete_sentence: Domani andrò dal dentista.
question_text: Domani ___ dal dentista.
english_translation: Tomorrow I will go to the dentist.
explanation: Andrò is the future simple first person singular of andare. The future tense expresses actions that will happen.

complete_sentence: Il bagno è accanto alla cucina.
question_text: Il bagno è accanto ___ cucina.
english_translation: The bathroom is next to the kitchen.
explanation: Alla (a + la) is the contracted form required after 'accanto' (next to), which takes the preposition 'a'.

complete_sentence: Mangiate la verdura e bevete l'acqua!
question_text: ___ la verdura e bevete l'acqua!
english_translation: Eat the vegetables and drink the water!
explanation: The imperative form for 'voi' (you plural) of 'mangiare' is 'mangiate'. This matches with 'bevete' which is also voi form.

complete_sentence: Vado spesso alla palestra del mio quartiere.
question_text: Vado spesso ___ palestra del mio quartiere.
english_translation: I often go to the gym in my neighborhood.
explanation: 'Alla' (a + la) indicates movement toward a destination. 'Andare a' requires the preposition 'a' with the definite article.

complete_sentence: La mia casa si trova in una strada tranquilla.
question_text: La mia ___ si trova in una strada tranquilla.
english_translation: My house is located on a quiet street.
explanation: 'Casa' (house) fits the context of being located on a street, while other options don't make logical sense in this context.

complete_sentence: La mia professoressa d'inglese è molto brava.
question_text: La mia ___ d'inglese è molto brava.
english_translation: My English teacher is very good.
explanation: Feminine singular form of 'professore' is 'professoressa' to agree with 'la mia'

complete_sentence: Ho comprato duemila libri per la biblioteca.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ libri per la biblioteca.
english_translation: I bought two thousand books for the library.
explanation: Numbers from 1000 upward are written as one word: duemila, tremila, etc.

complete_sentence: Voglio comprare dei pantaloni nuovi per l'estate.
question_text: Voglio comprare ___ pantaloni nuovi per l'estate.
english_translation: I want to buy some new pants for the summer.
explanation: Partitive article 'dei' indicates 'some' with masculine plural nouns

complete_sentence: Quando ero piccolo, andavo sempre a scuola a piedi.
question_text: Quando ero piccolo, ___ sempre a scuola a piedi.
english_translation: When I was little, I always went to school on foot.
explanation: The imperfetto 'andavo' is used for habitual actions in the past. The word 'sempre' (always) indicates a repeated action, requiring the imperfetto tense.

complete_sentence: Gli studenti vanno all'università tutti i giorni.
question_text: Gli studenti vanno ___ tutti i giorni.
english_translation: The students go to the university every day.
explanation: The preposition 'a' + 'la' contracts to 'alla', but before a vowel we use the elision 'all'' for smoother pronunciation.

complete_sentence: Nella mia classe ci sono venticinque compagni.
question_text: ___ mia classe ci sono venticinque compagni.
english_translation: In my class there are twenty-five classmates.
explanation: The articulated preposition 'nella' (in + la) indicates location inside a space. It's the combination of 'in' + 'la'.

complete_sentence: Per secondo, prendo il pesce con le verdure.
question_text: Per ___, prendo il pesce con le verdure.
english_translation: For the second course, I'll have the fish with vegetables.
explanation: In Italian restaurants, 'secondo' refers to the main course (meat or fish), while 'primo' is pasta/rice, 'antipasto' is appetizer, and 'dolce' is dessert.

complete_sentence: Vado dal medico domani mattina.
question_text: Vado ___ medico domani mattina.
english_translation: I'm going to the doctor tomorrow morning.
explanation: The articulated preposition 'dal' (da + il) is used to indicate going to a person's place or professional office.

complete_sentence: Milano è più grande di Torino.
question_text: Milano è ___ grande di Torino.
english_translation: Milan is bigger than Turin.
explanation: The comparative of superiority is formed with 'più... di' to express 'more... than' or '-er than'.

complete_sentence: Ieri ti sono piaciute le lasagne?
question_text: Ieri ___ sono piaciute le lasagne?
english_translation: Did you like the lasagna yesterday?
explanation: With 'piacere' in the past tense, 'ti' is the indirect object pronoun for 'you'. 'Sono piaciute' agrees with the feminine plural subject 'le lasagne'.

complete_sentence: Questa macchina costa duemila euro.
question_text: Questa macchina costa ___ euro.
english_translation: This car costs two thousand euros.
explanation: Numbers in the thousands are written as one word: 'duemila' (2000), 'tremila' (3000), etc.

complete_sentence: Ho comprato una mela e delle pere.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ mela e delle pere.
english_translation: I bought an apple and some pears.
explanation: The indefinite article 'una' is used for a single, specific feminine noun. 'Delle' is the partitive article for 'some' with plural feminine nouns.

complete_sentence: Vuoi il caffè? No, non lo voglio.
question_text: Vuoi il caffè? No, non ___ voglio.
english_translation: Do you want coffee? No, I don't want it.
explanation: The direct object pronoun 'lo' replaces masculine singular nouns like 'il caffè'. It comes before the conjugated verb.

complete_sentence: Nella mia città vivono circa trecentomila abitanti.
question_text: Nella mia città vivono circa ___ abitanti.
english_translation: In my city about three hundred thousand inhabitants live.
explanation: Large numbers are written as one word: trecentomila, not separated

complete_sentence: Stamattina sono andato al supermercato con mia madre.
question_text: Stamattina ___ andato al supermercato con mia madre.
english_translation: This morning I went to the supermarket with my mother.
explanation: The verb 'andare' uses auxiliary 'essere' in passato prossimo

complete_sentence: Il fine settimana prossimo andremo al mare con gli amici.
question_text: Il fine settimana prossimo ___ al mare con gli amici.
english_translation: Next weekend we will go to the seaside with friends.
explanation: Future tense 'andremo' expresses future plans indicated by 'prossimo'

complete_sentence: La sera di solito ceno alle otto e poi guardo la TV.
question_text: La sera di solito ___ alle otto e poi guardo la TV.
english_translation: In the evening I usually have dinner at eight and then watch TV.
explanation: 'Cenare' specifically means 'to have dinner' and is used for evening meals

complete_sentence: La mia migliore amica è molto simpatica e generosa.
question_text: La mia migliore amica è molto ___ e generosa.
english_translation: My best friend is very nice and generous.
explanation: Adjective 'simpatica' must agree with feminine singular noun 'amica'

complete_sentence: Nel frigo ci sono delle uova e del latte.
question_text: Nel frigo ci sono ___ uova e del latte.
english_translation: In the fridge there are some eggs and some milk.
explanation: The partitive article indicates an unspecified quantity ('some'). For the feminine plural noun 'uova', the correct partitive article is 'delle' (di + le).

complete_sentence: Ho comprato dei pomodori freschi al mercato.
question_text: Ho comprato ___ pomodori freschi al mercato.
english_translation: I bought some fresh tomatoes at the market.
explanation: The partitive article 'dei' (di + i) is used to express an unspecified quantity ('some') for masculine plural nouns starting with a consonant, like 'pomodori'.

complete_sentence: Mettiamo i documenti nella borsa prima di uscire.
question_text: Mettiamo i documenti ___ borsa prima di uscire.
english_translation: Let's put the documents in the bag before going out.
explanation: To say 'in the', you must use an articulated preposition. The preposition 'in' combines with the feminine singular article 'la' to form 'nella'. 'In la' is never correct.

complete_sentence: Che ne dici di andare al mare questo fine settimana?
question_text: Che ne dici di ___ al mare questo fine settimana?
english_translation: What do you say we go to the seaside this weekend?
explanation: The expression 'Che ne dici di...?' is used to make a suggestion or an invitation. It is always followed by a verb in the infinitive form, such as 'andare'.

complete_sentence: Devi studiare di più per l'esame.
question_text: ___ studiare di più per l'esame.
english_translation: You must study more for the exam.
explanation: The modal verb 'dovere' (must/have to) expresses obligation. 'Devi' is the second person singular form followed by infinitive 'studiare'.

complete_sentence: Marco le ha regalato dei fiori.
question_text: Marco ___ ha regalato dei fiori.
english_translation: Marco gave her some flowers.
explanation: The indirect object pronoun 'le' means 'to her/to you (formal)'. It comes before the auxiliary verb in compound tenses.

complete_sentence: Il film sta per iniziare al cinema.
question_text: Il film ___ iniziare al cinema.
english_translation: The movie is about to start at the cinema.
explanation: 'Stare per + infinitive' expresses an action that is about to happen in the immediate future.

complete_sentence: Domani sera andiamo a teatro insieme.
question_text: ___ sera andiamo a teatro insieme.
english_translation: Tomorrow evening we're going to the theater together.
explanation: 'Domani sera' (tomorrow evening) indicates future plans. The present tense 'andiamo' can express planned future actions.

complete_sentence: Vado sempre in palestra la mattina.
question_text: Vado ___ in palestra la mattina.
english_translation: I always go to the gym in the morning.
explanation: The frequency adverb 'sempre' (always) typically comes after the verb in Italian and indicates a repeated action.

complete_sentence: Vado al centro commerciale per comprare dei vestiti nuovi.
question_text: Vado al centro commerciale per ___ dei vestiti nuovi.
english_translation: I'm going to the shopping center to buy some new clothes.
explanation: 'Comprare' means 'to buy' and is the correct verb for shopping activities

complete_sentence: Conosco bene Milano perché ci vivo da cinque anni.
question_text: Conosco bene Milano perché ___ vivo da cinque anni.
english_translation: I know Milan well because I've been living there for five years.
explanation: The particle 'ci' means 'there' and refers to a place previously mentioned

complete_sentence: Mia nonna viene sempre a trovarci la domenica.
question_text: Mia nonna viene ___ a trovarci la domenica.
english_translation: My grandmother always comes to visit us on Sundays.
